title: 105_s2083
content: The Act titled "Class Action Fairness Act of 1998" requires notification of class action certification or settlement under a new chapter in the United States Code. The Act "Class Action Fairness Act of 1998" defines terms related to class actions, including 'class,' 'class action,' 'class certification order,' 'class member,' and 'class counsel.' The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 defines terms related to class actions, such as 'class counsel,' 'plaintiff class action,' and 'proposed settlement.' It applies to all plaintiff class actions filed in Federal court and State court if any class member resides outside the State where the action is filed and the incident occurred in more than one State. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 requires class counsel to notify State attorney generals and the Department of Justice of proposed class action settlements within 10 days of filing. This includes providing relevant documents and information to ensure transparency and participation of class members. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 mandates that class counsel must inform State attorney generals and the Department of Justice about proposed class action settlements within 10 days of filing. This involves sharing key details such as proposed settlements, agreements between class counsel and defendants, final judgments, and relevant judicial opinions. Additionally, information on class members residing in each State attorney general's respective State and their estimated claim to the settlement must be provided. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 requires that a hearing for final approval of a settlement cannot be held before 120 days after notifying State attorneys general and the Department of Justice. Courts overseeing plaintiff class actions must ensure that notices to the class include a plain language summary of the case, legal consequences of joining, and the option to remove the case to Federal court if initially filed in State court. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 mandates that class action notices must include details on proposed settlement agreements, such as benefits, rights being waived, obligations on defendants, attorney's fees estimate, and fee calculation explanation. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 requires class action notices to include information on proposed settlement agreements, including benefits, rights waived, obligations on defendants, attorney's fees estimate, fee calculation explanation, and details on potential class members and their right to opt out. Compliance with this section does not grant immunity from legal action under Federal or State law. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 outlines provisions for class action settlements, including the rights of class members to refuse agreements if State attorney general notice is not provided. It also limits attorney's fees in class actions to a reasonable percentage of the settlement amount. The Class Action Fairness Act of 1998 limits attorney's fees in class actions to a reasonable percentage of damages, prejudgment interest, and costs incurred by defendants in complying with injunctive orders or settlement agreements. SEC. 3. DIVERSITY JURISDICTION FOR CLASS ACTIONS. Section 1332 of title 28, United States Code is amended to give district courts original jurisdiction over class actions where the matter exceeds $75,000 and involves plaintiffs and defendants from different states or countries. The amendment to Section 1332 of title 28, United States Code grants district courts original jurisdiction over class actions where the total amount in dispute exceeds $75,000 and involves plaintiffs from one state and defendants from another state or country. The amendment also allows for aggregation of individual claims in a class action to meet the jurisdictional threshold. Additionally, the district court is required to dismiss any civil action that falls under this jurisdictional provision and cannot proceed as a class action under Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF CLASS ACTIONS TO FEDERAL COURT. Section 1453 of Chapter 89 of title 28, United States Code, allows for the removal of class actions to a district court of the United States. This can be done by any defendant without the consent of all defendants, or by a plaintiff class member who is not a named or representative class member without the consent of all members of the class. This section applies to class actions both before and after the certification of a class. This can be done by any defendant without the consent of all defendants, or by a plaintiff class member who is not a named or representative class member without the consent of all members of the class. The amendment in Section 1446(b) of title 28, United States Code, clarifies the 30-day filing period requirement for removal of cases. SEC. 5. Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is amended to mandate sanctions for violations, including attorneys' fees and nonmonetary directives. Sanctions can also be imposed on a party's attorneys. SEC. 6. Effective Date. The amendments made by this Act will take effect 1 year after enactment and apply to civil actions pending or filed on or after that date.
